abstract.p: James May letter on July 16 travel article on crime in foreign cities recalls pickpocketing incident on Paris Metro (S)

block.p: To the Editor: Regarding ''Crime Takes a Vacation (Yours)'' (July 16): We visited Paris during the French Open a couple of months ago. The city was crowded with tourists and the lines were long and tiresome: in short, a paradise for pickpockets.

My turn came on one of the busiest subway lines in the direction of the Arc de Triomphe. It was standing room only and I was surrounded by three kids, aged maybe 8 to 14. They communicated by eye contact and did not utter a word. They had already established that I did not carry my wallet in my rear pocket but in the right front pocket. As the doors opened, the youngest already had his hands in my pocket.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Crime Takes a Vacation (Yours)'' (July 16): We visited Paris during the French Open a couple of months ago. The city was crowded with tourists and the lines were long and tiresome: in short, a paradise for pickpockets.

My turn came on one of the busiest subway lines in the direction of the Arc de Triomphe. It was standing room only and I was surrounded by three kids, aged maybe 8 to 14. They communicated by eye contact and did not utter a word. They had already established that I did not carry my wallet in my rear pocket but in the right front pocket. As the doors opened, the youngest already had his hands in my pocket.

I did not feel a thing, but my wife, having found a seat, observed it all. She gave me such a big jerk that the young thief was startled and had to leave the station empty-handed. I was very fortunate.
